user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of cleanup_upgraded_connection:
```c
static void
cleanup_upgraded_connection (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = connection->urh;

  if (NULL == urh)
    return;
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  /* Signal remote client the end of TLS connection by
   * gracefully closing TLS session. */
  if (0 != (connection->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS))
    gnutls_bye (connection->tls_session,
                GNUTLS_SHUT_WR);

  if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != urh->mhd.socket)
    MHD_socket_close_chk_ (urh->mhd.socket);

  if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != urh->app.socket)
    MHD_socket_close_chk_ (urh->app.socket);
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  connection->urh = NULL;
  free (urh);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions were detected in the provided function. I inspected the code for common non‑standard constructs that compilers document as extensions (examples: __attribute__(), __asm__/__asm__(), typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, __extension__, GCC/Clang builtin magic like __builtin_*, zero‑length arrays as extension, and other vendor keywords). The code only contains standard C constructs: a static function definition, pointer dereferences, NULL checks, preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT), calls to external/library functions (gnutls_bye, MHD_socket_close_chk_, free), and macro/constants (MHD_USE_TLS, MHD_INVALID_SOCKET, GNUTLS_SHUT_WR). Preprocessor conditionals and use of external library APIs/macros are not compiler language extensions per the rule. The left‑hand NULL comparison style (if (NULL == urh)) is a stylistic idiom, not an extension. Therefore there are no fragments that need to be reported for Rule 1.2.
